misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the scanner.next() method will read a student's full name, even if it contains spaces (e.g., 'Alice Smith').
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Java Scanner.next() method is token-based, meaning it delimits input by whitespace. If a student's name includes a space, scanner.next() will only consume the first part of the name, leaving the rest in the input buffer. This would cause an InputMismatchException when the next loop attempts to read an integer, or it would misalign the parallel arrays.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the number of students (N) will always be at least 1, and that the calculated index (n - 1) will always be a valid array index.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to account for the 'notional machine' behavior when N=0. If N=0, the arrays are initialized with size 0, and accessing names[n - 1] (which resolves to names[-1]) will cause the program to crash. A robust mental model of array execution requires checking if the collection is empty before accessing elements by index.
